awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Real-time Analysis and Feedback during Colonoscopy to improve Quality
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase II project will develop an assistive software tool for endoscopists to have real-time feedback of objective quality for colon and potential polyp region examinations. The technology is aimed to reduce polyp miss rates during colonoscopy. Colonoscopy has contributed to a marked decline in colorectal cancer related deaths.  However, recent data suggest that there is a significant miss rate for the detection of even large polyps and cancers.  Studies suggest that polyp detection rate may be related to the duration of the withdrawal phase of the procedure and cancer miss rate is related to the identity of the endoscopist performing the procedure. This tool, which will provide video stream analysis and feedback during live colonoscopy, is made up of novel middleware software to ensure high performance execution of video analysis on an affordable workstation, and are generic, reconfigurable with new task allocation that support time-constraint video analysis.  Objective metrics for real-time feedback are derived from real time analysis that will address complexities arising from blurry frames, stool, camera movement patterns, and regions of appendiceal orifice and polyps.  Technical insights learned from development of this tool for colonoscopy may be applicable to new research on quality control using videos generated in other areas of medicine, such as bronchoscopy, cystoscopy, arthroscopy and laparoscopy.

The broader/commercial impact of this project, if successfully implemented in large-scale day-to-day medical settings, will be higher quality of care for patients undergoing colonoscopy procedures with real time objective quality assessment, which is currently not feasible.  Over 14 million colonoscopies are performed annually in the US.  This assistive tool will stimulate high quality inspection, while documentation is done.  That will mean that endoscopists will be able to spend more time on performing the colonoscopy and less time on documentation.  Hospital/clinic administrators will be able to run endoscopic facilities more efficiently.  Insurance companies may benefit from better documentation and lower costs since fewer patients will require extensive cancer treatment as the frequency of missed polyps and early cancers declines. This assistive tool is also expected to contribute to medical education, research, and practice by providing automated feedback during teaching and training of novice endoscopists or continuing education for experienced endoscopists.

por.por_cntn:
As a result of the Small Business Technology Transfer Phase II funding, EndoMetric successfully developed novel software technology that performs real-time analysis of colonoscopy video and provides visual feedback to assist the endoscopist toward optimal inspection of the colon during colonoscopy. The ultimate goal is to reduce the polyp miss rate in colonoscopy practice reported in the recent literature.

From a video stream of the inner lining of the colon (colon mucosa), the software computes the amount of stool in the colon (to determine quality of the colon preparation by the patient and the cleaning effort made by the endoscopist), the time duration in which the colon mucosa is partially or clearly seen, candidate polyps, and the quality of the mucosa inspection. The feedback may be given throughout the withdrawal phase of the procedure or as the summary at the end of the procedure. The software consists of the middleware that routes video data and computed results among various software components for different types of image analysis and feedback. The software has been tested in two teaching rooms in a large endoscopy unit. Using overlay technology where feedback is projected on top of the endoscopy image, we conducted a controlled clinical trial on third-year GI trainees and found that our software improved quality of mucosa inspection.  Finally, in preparation for a large clinical trial and to decrease implementation costs we developed a second overlay system.

Broader Impacts: (1) The project enabled automated, objective quality assistance for colonoscopy in large-scale day-to-day medical settings, which was not feasible before. If adopted in colonoscopy practice, the software has the potential to directly benefit millions of patients undergoing colonoscopy. Insurance companies may benefit from better documentation and less reimbursement due to a longer surveillance interval and less cancer treatment cases since fewer polyps and cancer are missed. (2) The project has contributed to medical education, research, and practice for teaching and training of GI trainees. (3) The project has contributed directly to research-based training of five PhD students and two undergraduate students and a number of conference and journal publications. The scientific knowledge gained during the project has also been used for teaching of graduate students. The project was used as an example to motivate freshmen and high school students about broader impacts of computer science.
